Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Ceramic-on-Ceramic vs. Metal-on-Polyethylene Bearings in Total Hip Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: In a multicenter randomised controlled trial, 189 patients (216 hips) were enrolled

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either alumina ceramic bearings (144 hips) or cobalt chrome-on-polyethylene bearings (72 hips)

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the long-term survivorship and osteolysis incidence of ceramic-on-ceramic bearings compared to metal-on-polyethylene bearings in total hip arthroplasty.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the survivorship of the bearing surface and implant systems over a minimum of 10 years, with an average follow-up of 10.3 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The Kaplan-Meier survivorship analysis showed no significant difference in bearing-related failures between the ceramic (99.1%) and control groups (98.9%).

Harms.evidence: Squeaking occurred in 1.4% of the ceramic group.

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.
